He's seeking his second loan from ACB, to be used to buy 20 sacks of chicken food and pay his workforce. His strategy for growing his business is to lower the price of eggs to attract customers, and to bolster the capacity of his henhouse to meet market demand.

In the future, he'd like to become a wholesaler of eggs and chicken meat and to get married soon.

loans.use: to buy 20 sacks of chicken food and pay his workforce

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kassem is a 41 year-old married man and father of three children.  He works as car mechanic and opened his garage in 1987.  Kassem works hard to improve his business and keeps his garage supplied with everything this business might need.

Kassem requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase his battery stock, because, in addition to fixing cars, he also sells car batteries and electronics. Kassem works hard for his family's safety and satisfaction.  He insists on providing them with the best things they need. He hopes he can continue providing the best education and be proud of them in the future.

loans.use: To increase his stock of batteries

loans.name: Ekaterine

texts.en:
Ekaterine is 33 years old. She lives in Sagarejo, Kakheti Region. Ekaterine lives with her parents. Her mother works as a librarian in the local library and her father works as a night-watchman. 

Ekaterine earns income from sewing. She sews children’s clothes and sells them at the Lilo open market. The monthly income from this business is 600 Laris. The clothes are of a good quality, and she doesn’t have problems with distribution. 

Ekaterine requested credit for purchasing a new, modern sewing machine. She already has one, but it is old and out-of-order. With the new sewing machine, Ekaterine will be able to increase the assortment of the products as well as production volume. She will gain more customers at the market. It will positively impact her income and living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine for clothing business

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng sells groceries and earns $5 per day. She is a single mother with 2 children.  One of them works in the factory and earns $2.50 per day. Every month, Chheng has to spend $89 on food, $15 on electricity and $20 transportation. 

Chheng would like a loan of $500 to buy more grocery goods to sell. In the future, she wants to buy a store for herself.  At present, she is helping to make her daughter's store run well.   She would also like to get a shop for her son to do motorbike repairing so that he can have his own career and support himself.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Iman

texts.en: Iman is a 33-year-old mom who is also sales manager at one of the Jordanian companies. In her free time after work, she makes baskets from straw as a hobby. Using her experience in sales, she started a year ago selling cosmetics products at home, which gave her the curiosity to learn more about skin cleansing,  Now Iman has applied for this loan to buy specialized equipment for skin and facial cleansing to move on with this business.

loans.use: To buy facial and skin cleansing equipment

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is 60 years old and married with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ofelia has a bakery business in the Philippines. Ofelia requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for making bread.

Ofelia has been in this business for two years. Ofelia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making bread

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Simiyu

texts.en:
Simiyu is a resident of Kitale in Western Kenya.  She has been growing maize and beans for the last year.  She is married, with one child under 2 years old.  She runs a boutique for additional income.

Simiyu has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the new dairy cow will boost the family farming income and livelihood. She remains optimistic she will be able to own three quality dairy cows.

 She is concerned about unpredictable market conditions but has faith in Juhudi's loan services

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla, 46 years old, is a photographer and also sells some vegetables at home. She is a single mother with 5 children.  Four are studying and one just finished studying motorbike repair. Every month, she has to spend $35 on food, $24 on school fee, and $10 for other expenses. 

She would like a loan of $900 to buy a camera for continuing her career. She wants to buy a modern camera so that she can take good photos for her customers. In the future, if she is able to save enough money, she would like to get a small shop for her son to do motorbike repairs.  She is afraid he might forget what he has learned from school. She wants to send the rest of her children to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy a camera for being a photographer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 50 years old and has six children. Evangeline is married and four of her children are in school.

Evangeline is in the agricultural business farming rice in the Philippines. Evangeline requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Evangeline has been farming rice for 13 years now, and has borrowed 11 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. In the future, Evangeline would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a hard working and entrepreneurial 31-year-old businessman. His alternative source of income comes from the earnings he gets from his general store. Previously he was employed. He is married and blessed with two children aged 4 years and 7 months. One of the children is in school. He has been meeting the needs of his family for the last four years by providing bureau services. He wants in the next five years to have a big wholesale shop and his dream is to be a big businessman who has ventured out of the borders.

He is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy toner and cartridges. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to accumulate a wealth of information about businesses from their informative seminars.

loans.use: to buy toner and cartridges

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en: Robinah lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has five children, one of whom is in school. Robinah has a business selling at a food stall. She has been in this business for 10 years and she works seven days out of every week.  Robinah sells her products at the market at retail.  Robinah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of Irish and sweet potatoes.  She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Robinah include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build more rental rooms and to sell at wholesale only. Robinah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of Irish potatoes and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Samoun

texts.en: Samoun, 41 year old, is a farmer with her husband. Their income is $6 per day. She has three children. All of the children are studying. Every month she has to spend $32 on food, $20 on school fees, $10 transportation, and $15 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a rice-throwing machine for planting the villager's rice seed to get some income. In the future, she wants to buy a hand tractor for doing plowing of the villager's farm if she has enough money. For her children, she will try to support them to study and at least finish high school.

loans.use: To buy a rice-throwing machine

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary works hard to support her family. Rosemary is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Rosemary requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her stall.

Rosemary has been in this business for 16 years.

In the future, Rosemary would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a chuff cutter for his dairy farming.

loans.name: Sart

texts.en: Sart, 36 years old, is a grocery seller. Her husband is a motor taxi driver.  Their income is $14 per day. She has 3 children, all of whom are studying. Every month, she has to spend $45 on food, $10 on electricity, $20 on school fees, $20 on transportation, and $10 on other expenses. She would like a loan of $1200 to buy more grocery goods to sell. She plans to extend her grocery store so that she can provide goods to other stores and customers. From the profits she earns, she wants to repair her house and send her children to study in the university.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa works hard to support 6 children. She is married and has a sugarcane farming business in the Philippines.

Elsa requested a PHP 3,500 loan through NWTF to buy a SOLAR LAMP.  She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have a good light-source that is waterproof during the rainy season.

Elsa is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, but she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a solar lamp

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a water pump and buy poultry birds

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Sun is a tailor. Her husband is a village leader.  Their income is $15 per day. She lives with one daughter and her husband. Every month, she has to spend $50 on food, $15 on electricity, $15 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. She would like a loan of $1000 to buy fabric for making clothes to sell. She hopes her career will be successful and she will be able to make good income so that she can send her daughter to study medical care in Phnom Penh city.

loans.use: To buy fabric for making clothes to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine has been a farmer in her home area of Kitale in Western Kenya for 19 years and currently employs one farmhand. Her farm produces maize, beans, milk and vegetables. She runs a transport business as well as low cost rental houses. She is married with 8 children, five of whom are still in school.

Christine has made a loan request amounting to 100,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to construct a poultry shed and purchase the poultry birds for her new venture. She says the business will act as the source of food and provide school fees for the education of the children. She aspires to be a breeder of both dairy and poultry

She concurs with other farmers that the running cost for diseases is a great challenge.

loans.use: to pay for construction of poultry unit and buy poultry birds

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora works hard to support her family. Leonora is a widow and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Leonora requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business. Leonora has been in this business for 4 years.

Leonora would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Conegonda

texts.en:
Conegonda is 65 years old and a widow with 7 children. 

Conegonda is in an agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Conegonda requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Conegonda has been raising pigs for 12 years now and has borrowed 13 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Conegonda would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Nary, 42 years old, is a pig feeder. Her husband is a farmer.  Their income is $14 per day. She has four children, all of whO. are studying. Every month, she has to spend $90 on food, $25 on rent, $20 on school fees, $10 on transportation, and $20 on other expenses. 

She would like a loan of $600 to buy pigs and pig feed.  She plans to get a pig farm with her husband when she can save money.  She plans to send her children to study in the university.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise and sell

loans.name: Phelista

texts.en:
Phelista is a resident of Kitale, Western Kenya and fully relies on her farming. She has been farming for the last 20 years as her only source of liivelihood. Her farm produces milk, maize, beans and vegetables. She is married with three adult children.

Phelista has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She says this will increase her milk production and boost her income tremendously, thereby enabling her to expand her business.

Phelista says the high costs for animal feed and management of disease remain the major challenges. She is pleased with Juhudi's interventions for farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan, 55, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow with two children. Her elder child is in college and the younger in high school.  She and her children manage their own household while operating a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one bottle of shampoo, a Php5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Susan gets supplies at wholesale prices and sells by the piece. Her store is located inside her house. At the same time she also manages an adjacent extension of their house as a room for rent. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 28,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and for the maintenance of their room for rent. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Susan hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.  There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and for the maintenance of her room for rent

loans.name: Chausiku

texts.en:
Chausiku is age 28 and has been in farming for three years. She produces maize, beans and eggs, which she sells locally in Kitale, western Kenya. She is single with one child who is seven years old. She runs a salon for additional income.

Chausiku has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow, which she believes will enable her to give basic provisions to her child. She is optimistic the business will grow and she aspires to become a prominent breeder in the future.

However, she laments about the poor prices for dairy products.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Danson

texts.en:
Danson is a hardworking and ambitious 52 year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with three children, aged 15, 12, and 6, who are in school. He has been making a living for the last 3 years by operating a general store as a supplement to his income from the earnings he gets from his car wash business. He wants to have made his business self sustaining in the next 5 years so that he is able to realize his dream of transforming it into a wholesale shop.

He is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to boost his business from the finances advanced to him.

loans.use: to buy sugar, wheat flour, cooking oil etc

loans.name: Rysbu's Group

texts.en:
Rysbu is the leader of this group. She is 29 and married to a builder.   She and her husband are raising two daughters and a son, all of whom are preschool age (under seven).  Rysbu works as a teacher at school. Seven years ago, she saved her salary and spent it on purchasing two livestock animals. She breeds livestock and then resells it at the higher price. With the profits gained from this activity she purchased household appliances and improved the family’s living conditions. With money received from the loan, Rysbu wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future she wishes to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Mogesa

texts.en:
Mogesa is a resident and a farmer in Kitale where he has been farming for the last 10 years. He currently employs four farmhands. His farm produces maize, tomatoes and milk, which he sells at the local market. He is married with three children all schooling and earns additional income from livestock trade.

Mogesa has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the loan will improve his family living standards. He hopes to grow the business by buying more dairy cows and venturing into the poultry business in the future.

He says the major challenges remain finances, diseases and low prices for the products at the market.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah lives in Uganda.  She is single and has 7 children, all of whom are in school.  Hadjah  has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Hadjah sells her products at the market.  Hadjah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through roasting maize. The main business challenge(s) for Hadjah include seasonality and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only and also to buy a plot of land so that she can build her own house. Hadjah lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Guluskan's Group

texts.en:
Guluskan is the leader of this group. She is 26 and married to a construction worker. She and her husband are raising a boy and a girl. Two years ago Guluskan’s parents presented her with two livestock animals. In two years, she increased the number of livestock to 12 animals. She contributes about 10,000 soms per month to the family budget by reselling livestock after fattening them. 

Guluskan applied for the loan because she needs additional money for purchasing more livestock for breeding. In the future, with money gained from reselling livestock, she wishes to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene, 48, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson, a house painter. She has three children.

Arlene operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages  to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one bottle of shampoo, a Php5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also sells frozen meat products.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php900 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and frozen products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Arlene hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies with them.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and frozen products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy second-hand shoes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair a power saw.

loans.name: Muthoni

texts.en:
Muthoni, 27, is married to Wallace who is a technician. They are blessed with one seven-year-old child. Muthoni runs a retail shop which has been in operation for ten years. The business earns her a monthly income of 52,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). 

This is her first loan from KADET Ltd. She will use the funds to buy 90 kg of sugar, three bags of rice, and five bales of maize flour for resale. She intends to use the anticipated profits to open a bigger shop and hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, flour, and rice for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 41 years old and married to Henry; she has been operating her farming/green grocery business for the past five years. She earns a monthly income of about 12,500 Kenyan Shillings (KES) which she uses to take care of her business and family. 

She has been loaned 30,000 Kenyan Shilling (KES) from KADET Ltd. and intends to use the loan to fence her land; to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and farming tools; and to pay laborers. 

She plans to use the profit from her business to educate her children and provide for their basic needs. 

In the future, she hopes to be a reliable green grocer producer in Kathuani, support her family fully through education, and provide them with other comforts.

loans.use: To fence her land, to purchase seeds, fertilizer, farming tools, and to pay laborers.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul, aged 29, is married to Leah, and is blessed with one three-year-old child. He runs a boutique which has been in operation for nine years. The business earns him a monthly income of 41,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). 

This is his first loan with KADET Ltd. He will use the loan funds to buy new clothes for sale. He intends to use the anticipated profits to open another boutique and hopes to own a modern fashion house in the future.

loans.use: To buy new clothes for sale

loans.name: Momogul

texts.ru: Момогул проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст, 46 лет. Замужем, имеет двоих детей. Муж, работает таксистом. Сама она занимается торговлей. Она рядом с домом открыла минимаркет. В этой области Момогул уже 8 лет. Она берет кредит для приобретения нового холодильника и молочных продуктов.
texts.en: Momogul lives in the city of Vahdat.  She is 46 years old, married and has two children.  Her husband works as a taxi driver.  Momogul is involved in retail sales.  She opened a mini-market near her house.  Momogul has been in this business for eight years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of a new refrigerator and dairy products.

loans.use: to purchase a new refrigerator and dairy products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize seeds, French bean seeds and potatoes to plant

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, rice and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis, aged 40, is married and blessed with six children. He does farming, mainly tea growing and dairy keeping, which he has been doing for four years. The business earns him a monthly income of KES 30,000.

This is his first loan term with KADET LTD. He will use the loan funds to buy a dairy cow for milk production. He intends to use the expected profits to educate his children and hopes to be a renowned farmer in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow for milk production

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy, age 33, is a single mother of two children aged 9 and 11 years old. She sells curios and has been doing this for six years. The business earns her a monthly income of KES 12,000.

This is her first loan term with KADET LTD. She will use the funds to buy more stock of curios for sale. She intends to use the expected profits to pay school fees for her children and hopes to build a permanent house in the future.

loans.use: To buy more curios to sell

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en: Rosette lives in Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school.  Rosette has a beauty salon. She has been in this business for six years and she works seven days out of every week.  Rosette sells her products in a shop. Rosette has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cream relaxers and weaves. The main business challenges for Rosette include seasonality and transport.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked salon. Rosette lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves and braids

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school, owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 10 years, Mary has operated a second- hand clothing business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Having joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Mary has requested a Kshs 20,000 loan to purchase a bale of clothes for resale. Her major dream is to become a wholesale supplier of clothes in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Madija

texts.en:
Madija is a widowed woman with one child who graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, Madija has operated a street-food business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Seasonality is the major challenge she faces in her business.

Having decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Madija is requesting a loan of Kshs 10,000 to purchase bundles of cereals, beans, maize and peas. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of cereals, beans, maize and peas.

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran is 46 years old, married and has five children. She couldn't provide education facilities for all of her children due to the limited financial resources available. Only her youngest son, who is 9 years old, is studying in class 4th.

Her husband has a fruit-selling business. He puts fruit on his cart every morning and visits different streets in the city to sell by announcing in a loud voice. Sughran’s three elder sons also operate fruit-selling businesses like their father.  Sughran is a housewife and does her household responsibilities by staying at home. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to put more fruit in his cart to sell. This will add variety to his fruit and help him sell more to increase profits. Sughran is confident that through the loan, her husband’s income will increase and she will be able to provide better living facilities to her family as a result. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sughran.

loans.use: To buy fruits to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, who lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda, is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. She lives in a rented home that has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food for the family.

For the past five years, Florence has operated a bakery six days each week, retailing her products in a shop. Florence has requested a loan of 200000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more cartons of baking flour and cooking oil. Her main business challenges include seasonality and transport costs, and her business goal is to own a fully-stocked canteen.

loans.use: to buy more baking flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is rent.

For the past two years, he has operated a street food business, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He faces the major challenges of seasonality and perishability in his business. His major goal is to establish a restaurant business in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase more bundles of cereals and coconut for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase more bundles of cereals and coconut to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth lives in Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Ruth has a business selling second hand clothes .She has been in this business for seven years and she works seven days out of every week.  Ruth sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Ruth has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  She generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Ruth include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing clothes and to buy her own plot of land so that she can build her own house. Ruth lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shodigul

texts.ru: Шодигул проживает в городе Вахдат. Ей 45 лет. Она замужем. У нее двое детей. Ее муж находится на заработках в Российской Федерации. Сама Шодигул после отъезда мужа занялась шитьем национальных платьев. Она берет заказы у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности она занимается пять лет. Кредит берет для покупки тканей, чтобы сшить платья для продажи.
texts.en: Shodigul lives in the city of Vahdat.  She is 45 years old, married and has two children.  Her husband works in the Russian Federation.  Shodigul became involved in sewing national dresses after her husband's departure.  She fulfills her orders at home.  She has been involved in this business for five years.  Shodigul is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabrics in order to sew dresses for sale.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha, a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school, lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past 10 years, Mwanaisha has operated a food-vending business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Seasonality is the major challenge she faces, as during the rainy season it becomes difficult to operate her business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant in the future.

Having decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Mwanaisha is requesting a loan of Kshs 20,000 to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more curios and necklaces to sell.

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a Khanga-selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors, especially women. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major dream is to become a wholesale supplier in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of Khangas to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of Khangas

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith lives in Uganda. She is married and has six children, one of whom is in school. She has been in the retail business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Edith sells her products from home. Edith has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, cooking oil and bans of bread.  She generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenges for Edith include transportation and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and to educate her children up to university only. Edith lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and bread

loans.name: Mahtaroy

texts.ru: Махтарой проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 61 год. Разведена. Имеет двоих детей. Она живет вместе с родителями. У нее высшее образование, она по профессии экономист. В этой области Махтарой проработала 20 лет. На сегодняшний день она занимается растениеводством. В основном сеет пшеницу, рис, кукурузу и выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для повторного посева кукурузы.
texts.en: Mahtaroy lives in the Vahdat district.  She is 61 years old, divorced and has two children.  She lives together with her parents.  She has a secondary education, and is an economist by trade.  Mahtaroy had worked 20 years in that field.  Today, she is involved in agriculture.  She primarily plants wheat, corn and grows vegetables.  She is requesting this loan for a repeat planting of corn.

loans.use: to plant corn again

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth lives in Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Ruth has a business selling firewood.  She has been in this business for four years and she works seven days out of every week. Ruth sells her products at the market, by means of retail. Ruth has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bundles of firewood. The main business challenges for Ruth include seasonality and transport. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only. Ruth lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bundles of firewood

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a married man with one child who is still too young for school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and hospital bills.

For the past three years, he has operated a cosmetic shop business, selling to his neighbors and passersby. His greatest challenge is the high cost of transportation in his business. He dreams of expanding his business to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase beauty products, braids and weaves. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products, braids and weaves.

loans.name: Bagrat

texts.ru:
Баграту 53 года; он живет в селе Гегамаван Гегаркуникской области с женой и двумя сыновьями. Старший сын работает менеджером на пивоваренном заводе «Гюмри», а младший учиться в средней школе. Жена не работает, помогает Баграту в производстве и реализации сельскохозяйственной продукции. 
Сам Баграт после окончания техникума продолжил учебу в Ереванском институте народного хозяйства. Получив квалификацию экономиста, Баграт девять лет проработал на Гагаринской птицефабрике. С 1992 года занимался коммерческой деятельностью в разных городах России. 
Последние 10 лет, основным занятием Баграта является сельскохозяйственная деятельность. На своей ферме он разводит двух коров и двух телят, а также выращивает картофель и чеснок. Полученную молочную продукцию и овощи дважды в неделю отвозит на рынки Еревана. 
Баграт намерен приобрести еще одну корову и расширить производство чеснока, для чего ему необходим кредит в размере 1,000,000 драм.
texts.en: Bagrat is 53 years old and lives in the Geghamavan village in the Gegharkunik area together with his wife and two sons.  The oldest son works as a manager at the "Gyumri" brewery, and the youngest attends a secondary school.  His wife does not work and helps Bagrat with production and sales of agricultural products.  After finishing college, Bagrat continued his education at the Yerevan institute of national economy.  Once he achieved the qualification of an economist, Bagrat spent nine years working at the Gagarin bird factory.  He has been involved in commercial business in various Russian cities since 1992.  Bagrat has been primarily involved in agriculture for the past ten years.  He is raising two cows and two calves at his farm and also grows potatoes and garlic.  He takes obtained dairy products and vegetables to Yerevan markets twice per week.  Bagrat intends to purchase an additional cow and expand his garlic production, for which he needs to obtain a loan in the sum of 1,000,000 dram.

loans.use: To buy an additional cow and to increase garlic production

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié , père de deux enfants. Il exerce l'activité de mareyage qu'il a démarré il y'a sept ans avec des prêts de riches hommes d'affaires qui interviennent dans le secteur de la pêche artisanale comme bailleurs d fonds.Il n'est jamais arrivé à faire des bénéfices consistants du fait du fort taux d'usure appliqué par ses créanciers.En plus, il subissait une très forte pression car devant rembourser globalement en fin de journée tout le montant reçu le matin.Cette exploitation ne lui permettait pas d'avoir les revenus nécessaires pour prendre en charge les besoins alimentaires, sanitaires, d'habillement, de logement et de scolarité de sa famille.Pour se libérer des griffes de ces usuriers, il décide d'ouvrir un compte à l'IMCEC.Il obtient un premier prêt de 250 000FCFA sur 12 mois qu'il parvient à solder en 3 mois seulement et l'institution lui laisse les intérêts des 9 mois. C'est ainsi que sa part de marché s’élargit si bien qu'il approvisionne deux usines de traitement de poisson basées dans la capitale non loin de sa localité. Il ambitionne d'ailleurs de s'engager dans l'exportation du poisson frais en Europe et aux USA.Aujourd'hui, il sollicite un deuxième prêt de 350 000FCFA afin de satisfaire la forte demande en achetant 03 caisses de badége noir et 03 caisses de "thiof".Les bénéfices tirés de cet investissement serviront non seulement à prendre en charge les besoins de la famille mais participeront aussi à l'atteinte de son objectif à court terme qui est d'acheter et de construire sa propre maison.
texts.en: The borrower is a married man who is father to two children. He has a fish trading business which he started seven years ago with loans from rich businessmen who actively back small fishing businesses. He has never been able to make consistent profits as a result of the exorbitant interest rates applied by his creditors. Furthermore he was under huge pressure because he had to pay all the money he took in the morning by the end of the day. This business did not give him sufficient income to provide for his family's food, health, clothing, lodging and schooling. In order to break free from these loan sharks' claws, he decided to open an account with IMCEC (a Senegalese association of mutual loan and savings institutions). He had a first loan of 250,000FCFA over 12 months which he managed to repay in just three months, and the institution left him the interest for the remaining nine months. His market share has thus grown so much that he supplies two fish-processing factories in the capital not far from his town. His ambition is moreover to get involved in the export of fresh fish to Europe and the USA. Today he is requesting a second loan of 250,000FCFA in order to satisfy strong demand by buying three crates of black "badèches" (a sea fish) and three crates of "thiof" (another fish, common in Senegal). The profits he makes from this investment will be used not only to provide for his family's needs but will also contribute to him achieving his short-term objective which is to buy and construct his own house.

loans.use: to buy 6 boxes of fresh local fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes, sacks of beans, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is a 30-year-old Rwanadan entrepreneur with four children between the ages of 2 and 8 years old. The oldest two are in school. 

For the past four years, she has been running a general store with her husband. This business has enabled them to care for their family. 

She requires a loan to purchase more goods such as sugar, candles, and matches that she will sell in her store.

The profits generated from this business will allow her to make savings, feed her family, and pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, candles, and matches to sell

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is a 30-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has a 3-year-old child who is not yet in school.  

For the past 1.5 years, Vestine and her husband have been running a shop where they sell foodstuffs. This new business is doing well and the profits it has generated have provided for their family. This loan will allow them to expand their business as they will use it to purchase more goods such as sugar and rice to sell in their store. With profits from this business, Vestine will accumulate savings and provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar and rice to sell in her store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Uganda. She is single and has 4 children, three of whom are in school. Rose has operated a business selling different types of bananas for over 10 years, and she works 7 days every week. Rose sells her products at the market, by means of retail.

Rose has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income by selling fruits and vegetables. The main business challenges for Rose include seasonality and defaulters. Her goals and hopes for her business are to start going to farmers directly and to sell wholesale only. Rose lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food for the family.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of Cavendish bananas and sweet bananas

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Mme Salimata est mariée et mère de 07 enfants. Le plus âgé a 39ans et le moins âgé a 29ans. Personne ne va a l’école et elle a 06 personnes en charge.

Elle vend des pagnes traditionnels et des couvertures depuis 03ans. Mme s’approvisionne à Safané(Dédougou) et à Bobo Dioulasso toutes deux, des villes du Burkina.Ses clients sont les fonctionnaires des diférents services.
 
Elle veut s’acheter 15 pagnes traditionnels s et une dizaine de couvertures.

Mme utilise ses bénéfices pour les travaux de sa maison au fur et à mesure. Elle ambitionne agrandir son commerce et s’occuper de sa maison.
texts.en:
Salimata is married and the mother of 7 children. The oldest is 39 years old, and the youngest is 29. None attend school, and she has 6 persons to support. 

She's been selling traditional pagnes (colorful African cloth) and blankets for three years. She gets her supplies in Safané (Dédougou) and in Bobo Dioulasso, both cities in Burkina. Her customers are public servants from various offices.

She wants to buy 15 traditional pages and about ten blankets. As they come in, she will use her profits for work that her house needs. She ambitions to expand her business and take care of her house.

loans.use: to buy 15 traditional pagnes (colorful African cloth) and about 10 blankets

loans.name: Mohira

texts.ru: Мохира проживает в районе Файзобод. Ей 33 года. Она не замужем. У нее высшее педагогическое образование. По специальности она работает пять лет. Кроме того она занимается животноводством. Она разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. В основном она покупает телят, откармливает, а потом продает по более выгодной цене. В этой области она уже четыре года. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Mohira lives in the Fayzabad district.  She is 33 years old and single.  She has a higher education as a teacher.  She has been working in that field for five years.  Besides this, she is involved in animal husbandry.  Mohira breeds livestock for subsequent sale.  She primarily buys calves, fattens them up and then sells them at a more profitable price.  She has been in this field for four years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more retail commodities such as sugar, soap,cooking oil, maize flour, plastics, etc. to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cement, iron, corrugated zinc, nails, etc. in large quantities

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah lives in Uganda. She is single and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (three orphans). Hadjah lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity or to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food for the family.

Hadjah has operated a business selling tomatoes for 8 years, and she works 6 days every week. Hadjah sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes. The main business challenges for Hadjah include seasonality and thieves. Her goal and hope for her business is to start going to farmers for tomatoes.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes

loans.name: Zahriya

texts.en:
Zahriya is a 61-year-old widowed woman who wanted to have a stable income after her husband passed away. So she started a small retail business selling traditional clothes, challenging the fact that she’s an illiterate woman.

It has been six successful years now since she started her business. She has been supporting her youngest daughter who is 18 years old now. And since Zahriya is an ambitious woman who wants to expand her business, she decided to take a loan to have her own clothing store.

loans.use: to start her own clothing store

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
Gulsara is 55, married and has three children. She works as an English language teacher at the school in Tokmok and is known as an accurate and open-hearted teacher. Her husband, Turatbek, also works as a teacher in mathematics. In order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Gulsara began to develop her business in cattle breeding in 1995. She bought milk cows with her start-up capital of 20.000 KGS and managed to earn about 20,000 KGS in a month from selling milk products.

Gulsara plans to use her loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by buying two milk cows. With the revenues from these investments, she will be able to help her son to reconstruct his house and raise her family's living standards. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize seeds and tomatoes seeds for planting.

loans.name: Jeiko Porave Rekavo Group

texts.es:
El comité fue formado gracias a la iniciativa y entusiasmo de la señora María Ana, quien se enteró del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación a través de una conocida. La señora Ana contactó con sus vecinas y amigas emprendedoras para formar el comité en la zona. El grupo se denomina Jeiko Porave Rekávo, están en el Segundo Ciclo, con 15  integrantes. Es un comité muy unido, solidario y responsable, las integrantes poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor.
La Sra. Paulina tiene una despensa, por medio del cual ha podido salir adelante, por medio de su negocio ella ha podido generar mas ingresos con lo cual puede solventar todos los gastos de la casa. Ella sueña con algún día poder ampliar su negocio lo cual le servirá para poder tener mas espacio donde exhibir sus mercaderías.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de comestibles, bebidas, lácteos, y hortalizas para abastecer su negocio. Ella agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que le brinda.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to the initiative and enthusiasm of María Ana who found out about Fundación Paraguaya's Committee of Entrepreneurial Women program through an acquaintance.  Ana contacted her entrepreneurial friends and neighbors to set up a committee in their area.  The group is called Jeiko Porave Rekávo.  It is in its second loan cycle and has 15 members.  This is a very united, supportive and responsible committee.  The members have a great entrepreneurial spirit.

Paulina has a grocery store through which she has been able to get ahead in life.  Through her business, she has been able to make more income with which she is able to cover all her household expenses.  She dreams of some day being able to expand her business so that she has more space for displaying her merchandise.

Paulina is requesting a loan to buy food, drinks, dairy products and vegetables to stock her business.  She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity that they are giving her.

loans.use: to buy food, drinks, dairy products and vegetables to stock her store

loans.name: United Brothers Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very please to present to you members of the “United Brothers” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of SLL 800,000, for each, in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Salieu is the leader of this group. Salieu is 29-years old and married. He has 2 children, 1 of whom is attending primary school. Salieu sells mobile phone accessories and has been running this business for 5 years now. With his share of this loan he is going to buy mobile phone accessories in large quantities to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone accessories in large quantities to add to his business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane, aged 45, is a single mother of three children. She runs a green grocery and fruit stall. The business has been in operation for ten years and earns her a monthly income of KES 50,000.

This is her third loan term with KADET LTD. She has successfully managed to repay the previous loans. She will use the loan funds to buy vegetables and fruits for sale. She intends to use the anticipated profits to put up some rental units on her piece of land and hopes to have flats for rental in the future.

loans.use: to buy groceries and fruits for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Valentine

texts.en:
Valentine, age 29, is married to Cosmus and blessed with one child who is three years old. She operates a cereals shop but also has a boutique alongside. She has been doing these businesses for four years and earns a monthly profit of KES 15,000.

This is her first loan with KADET LTD. She will use the loan funds to buy more cereals and more clothes for her boutique. Valentine hopes to educate her child and buy a piece of land in the future.

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Subira

texts.en:
Subira is a 57-year-old villager who lives in Talas town. She is a very energetic and optimistic woman who is the main caretaker for her two grandchildren.  She is married with three adult children. The youngest child lives with her and helps in her business. To make a living, Subira is occupied with cattle breeding. In the beginning, she started with an initial capital of 12.000 KGS, which was used to purchase six sheep. Today, she manages to earn about 6.000 KGS a month selling meat products and is still looking forward to developing her farm in the near future. For this reason, Subira has requested a loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy 10 sheep. That allows her further development of her household and business. In the future, Subira plans to help her son build a house.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Stanely

texts.en:
Stanely, age 28, is a single man who runs a cafeteria that has been in operation for four years. The business earns him a monthly profit of KES 15,000.

This is his first loan with KADET LTD. He will use the loan funds to buy flour, cooking oil and other food supplies for his cafe. He intends to use the anticipated profits to open another cafe and hopes to own a huge restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To buy food supplies for the cafeteria like flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pesticides and chemicals

loans.name: Anzhela

texts.ru:
Анжеле 55 лет, она проживает в селе Вачаган, Сьюникского региона. Анжела окончила Капанский политехникум и получила специальность финансиста-экономиста. Более тридцати лет Анжела работает в Сбербанке. Живет вместе с мужем и вместе они занимаются пчеловодством и птицеводством. Их сын (который занимается частным бизнесом) и две дочери живут отдельно со своими семьями.
Анжела занимаются сельским хозяйством более 20 лет: она вместе с мужем разводит пчел и кур. Полученные на своей ферме мед и яйца они реализует в городе Капане в магазине сына. Также они имеет своих постоянных покупателей в Ереване и в Каджаране. 
Кредит на сумму 1.000.000 драм необходим Анжеле для приобретения новых ульев, парафина и рамок для меда.
texts.en:
Anzhela is 55 years old.  She lives in Vachagan village in the Syuniksky region. Anzhela graduated from Kapan Polytechnic with a degree in finance/economics.  She worked at a savings bank for more than thirty years. She lives her husband and together they keep bees and farm poultry.  Their son (who has his own business) and two daughters live separately with their own families.

Anzhela has been working in agriculture for more than twenty years.  She and her husband raise bees and hens. They sell their honey and eggs in Kapan in their son's shop. They also have steady customers in Yerevan and in Kadzharan.
 
Anzhela needs a loan for 1,000,000 drams to buy new beehives, beeswax, and frames for honey

loans.use: to buy new beehives, beeswax, and frames for honey

loans.name: We Day Pay Group

texts.en:
Meet with the members of the “We Day Pay” group from Kenema, in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 500,000 SLL for each person in the group. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Mohamed is the leader of this group. The 52-year-old is married to a trader and the couple has six children. Mohamed has been a businessman for 30 years now. He sells used clothes.  With his share of this loan, he will buy a large bundle of used clothes to add to his current ones.

loans.use: to buy a large bundle of used clothes to add to his stock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy dozens of decorative flowers to sell

loans.name: Otar

texts.en:
Otar, 45, lives in the village of Patardzeuli with his family: his wife Inga, a 22-year-old son who helps in the family business, and a 20-year-old daughter, who works as a teacher locally.

Otar and Inga run a family-owned dairy farm with four cows and a poultry farm with 2000 hens. Inga makes cheese which she sells at the local market and wholesales hens to local poultry retailers. With the requested loan, Otar plans to purchase feed for 1000 new chickens on the farm, and with the additional profits, the family members plan on improving their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase feed for chickens on his poultry farm.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cassava leaves and gallons of palm oil to add to her business

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
El comite denominado San Cayetano es de la Ciudad de Comcepcion, está integrado por 13 mujeres de la misma Ciudad. Ellas se encuentran en el segundo ciclo del programa trabajando de forma solidaria y dentro de un marco de respeto y de colaboracón. Lo que las motivo a formar el comité fue la idea de producir un bien para sus familias
Comentan ellas que trabajan muy duro para conseguir todos los fines que se propusieron, además manifiestan que todo lo que hacen es para generar un poco más de ingresos para sus familias y así tener un mejor futuro.
La Sra. Nancy se dedica a la venta venta de frazadas, sabanas, fundas, edredones y demás, gracias e este trabajo que realiza hace ya varios, puede solventar los gastos de la casa. Ella está muy orgullosa de lo que hace, ya que considera que es un trabajo digno y honesto. Ella sueña con algún día poder tener un local donde poder ofrecer sus mercaderías.
Ella solicita el credito para la compra de frazadas, edredones y demás, con lo que podrá abastecerse para esta época de invierno.
texts.en:
The 'San Cayetano' committee is from the city of Concepción.  It is made up of 13 women from the city.  They are on their second loan cycle within the program, working in a supportive manner, in a framework of respect and cooperation.  What motivated them to form their committee was the idea of doing something good for their families.

The ladies tell us that they work very hard to achieve all of the goals that they set themselves.  They also say that everything they do is done to make a little extra income for their families so that they can enjoy a better future.

Nancy sells bedspreads, sheets, pillowcases, comforters and other items.  Thanks to this work, which she has been doing for several years now, she is able to cover her household expenses.  She is very proud of what she does as she considers it to be decent and honest work.  She dreams of some day being able to have premises where she can sell her merchandise.

Nancy is requesting this loan to buy bedspreads, comforters and other items so that she can stock her business for this winter season.

loans.use: to buy bedspreads, comforters, etc.

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is a 29-year-old farmer from the village of Sartichala, East Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Nana, his mother and grandmother. She is retired. Zurab’s mother works as a cook in the same village. 

Zurab has five milk cows. He produces cheese and sells it in the village. The total average income of the family is 500 Laris. 

With the requested credit, Zurab plans to purchase one more milk cow. He will have 20% more cheese and the same increase in income from his dairy farm. He will use the increase in income to purchase more household goods to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase one milk cow

loans.name: Jaime De Jesús

texts.es:
Poco capital de trabajo, un local ubicado en la casa de sus padres y las ganas de salir adelante y de ofrecerle a sus vecinos un lugar tranquilo donde tomarse un refresco o una cerveza, fueron lo que motivó a Jaime a darle vida a su propio negocio, una salsamentaria que poco a poco y gracias a su dedicación ha ido creciendo. 

En el futuro Jaime espera ampliar su negocio y posicionarlo aún más en el sector. Actualmente este emprendedor de 55 años oriundo de Medellín-Colombia, necesita de un préstamo para comprar surtido propio de la canasta familiar y así ofrecer otro tipo de productos.
texts.en:
Little working capital, business premises located in his parents' home and a desire to get ahead and offer his neighbors a quiet place where they could enjoy a soft drink or a beer were what motivated Jaime to give birth to his own business, a delicatessen which, thanks to his commitment, has gradually grown.

In the future, Jaime hopes to expand his business and position it even better in the sector.  This 55 year-old entrepreneur, who is from Medellín in Colombia, currently needs a loan to buy basic household products so that he can sell other types of product.

loans.use: to buy basic household products

loans.name: Goyah Group

texts.en:
Jeneba is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Jeneba was born in the township of Tongo. She is married to a trader and the couple has two children who are attending secondary and primary schools, respectively. Jeneba sells palm oil and has been a businesswoman for nearly 13 years now. 

With the help of this loan, Jeneba and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. Jeneba will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business

loans.name: Msere

texts.en:
Msere, aged 62, is a widowed mother of three children. She has been selling milk for four years. The business earns her a monthly profit of KES 7,000.

This is Msere's second loan term with KADET LTD. She has successfully repaid her previous loan. Msere will use the funds to buy goats for resale. She hopes to sell the goats and milk to neighboring countries in the future.

loans.use: To buy goats for resale

loans.name: Armen

texts.ru:
Армен родился в 1964 г. в городе Каджаране, окончил среднюю школу села Давит-Бек, затем окончил Ереванский Политехнический институт по специальности инженер-механик. Женат, имеет сына и дочь. Жена работает вместе с Арменом в совместно созданном ателье. Сын работает в страховым агентом, дочка учится на на платном заочном отделении Ереванском педагогическом университете на пятом курсе.
С 1998 г.  занимается бизнесом: производит рабочую спецодежду, обувь, рабочие перчатки. Полученную продукцию он поставляет на восемь предприятий Капана и Каджарана. Полученную от бизнеса выгоду Армен тратит на содержание семьи и на оплату обучения дочери.
Сумма кредита в размере 1.000.000 драм необходима для закупки сырья: ткани, нити, пуговиц, подошвы, кожа и т.д.
Данный кредит является 11-ым по счету, полученным Арменом из организации Нор Оризон.
texts.en: Armen as born in 1964 in Kadzharan.  He finished Davit-Bek school and them graduated from the Erevan Polytechnic Institute and an engineer-mechanic.  He is married and has a son and daughter.  His wife works with Armen in their tailoring shop.  His son is an insurance agent and their daughter studies without a scholarship in her fifth year at Erevan Pedagological University.  He has been in business since 1998.  He manufactures specialized work clothes, shoes, work gloves.   He delivers his goods to eight enterprises in Kapan and Kadzharan. Armen spends his income on supporting his family and paying for his daughter's education.  He is taking out a loan of 1,000,000 drams to buy raw materials: fabric, thread, buttons, soles, leather, etc. This will be Armen's eleventh loan from Nor Orizon.

loans.use: to buy raw material (fabric, thread, buttons, soles, leather, etc.) for clothing manufacture.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.es:
La  Sra. Mabel es madre soltera de 2 hijos menores y viven en la casa de sus padres. Mabel empezó vendiendo empanadas por la calle, luego, gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación logro montar una pequeña despensa desde hace 2 años, es un sacrificio muy grande ya que ella madruga para realizar sus compras del mercado San Lorenzo, también realiza sus compras de Clorinda una vez por semana; de esta manera logra abaratar el costo, vender a buen precio y mantener su buena clientela. Comenta que tiene una buena clientela, ya que no solo vienen de su barrio a comprar, sino también de zonas aledañas.
Mabel solicita el crédito para la compra de comestibles, lácteos, bebidas y demás, en cantidad y de esa forma obtener mejores ganancias. En el futuro desea comprar un vehículo para realizar mejor su trabajo. Ella agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le brinda, ya que sabe que el crédito le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
Mabel is a single mother.  She has two dependent children and they live together in her parents' home.  Mabel started out selling empanadas in the street.  Then, thanks to her effort and commitment, she managed to set up a small grocery store two years ago.  This represents a very big sacrifice as she must get up early in the morning to do her shopping in San Lorenzo market.  She also shops in Clorinda once a week.  This enables her to lower her costs, sell at a good price and retain her good customers.  Mabel tells us that she has good customers who don't only come from her neighborhood to buy from her but also from neighboring areas.

Mabel is requesting this loan to buy food, dairy products, drinks and other products in bulk so that she can make better profits.  In the future, she would like to buy a vehicle so that she can carry out her work better.  She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity that they are giving her since she knows that the loan will be a great help to her.

loans.use: to buy food, dairy products, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Kutesa B Development Group

texts.en:
Getting into the good graces of prospective and established clients in any business undertaking is by and large a process that involves good rapport building, exceptional service and, at times, the offering of free service. In the course of the past 12 years, Sarah has exhibited all that as she goes about her clothing sales business at her boutique, just a stone's throw away from Kampala.

To start this business, Sarah, a good-natured mother of 4, banked on capital from her already established rental business. Sarah carries the conviction that there is invariably a silver lining in whatever bad unfolds. She has used this philosophy to extricate herself out of the narrowest of circumstances. This attribute, in combination with the fact that she works painstakingly and diligently hard, is a stock in trade that she says has played very much in the favor of her business.

Sarah has also been operating under the financial auspices of her husband, who often spares time to help at her boutique. In many respects, this has also contributed to the stability of her business. On the side, Sarah ekes out supplementary income from a rentals business. Her weekly gross income totals up to UGX 200,000. Sarah says this Kiva loan will come in handy to purchase more clothes to resell

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam, 45 years old, lives in the village of Kakabeti, in the Kakheti region. Mariam is married and lives with her husband, Akaki, two adult sons and two daughters-in-law. Mariam has a small grocery shop in the village and is also actively involved in the family's agricultural business. The family has 3 hectares of vineyard and sell their grapes at the local market. On another 3 hectares of land, they grow watermelons and sell the harvested fruit to retailers. 

The family's average monthly income is 1,200 GEL. Mariam is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and drugs to treat their watermelon plants for parasites. This investment will increase the quality of the harvested fruits and their potential price as well, raising the family's income. Mariam plans to use the increase in income to purchase household appliances in order to improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and drugs to treat their watermelon plants for parasites.

loans.name: Sabokhat

texts.en:
Sabokhat, 60 years old, is married and has four children. In order to find the means to cover all of her family's household expenses, she started a business in cattle breeding and land cultivating. With a start-up capital of 3,000 KGS, Sabokhat managed to develop a farm with two milk cows. She also has a greenhouse with cabbages, onions and tomatoes and grows corns and potatoes on the homestead land. All of these activities allow Sabokhat to earn about 10,000 KGS in season.

Sabokhat plans to use this loan of 70,000 KGS to purchase cattle as well as fertilizers to manure her land. With the revenues, she plans a further broadening of her business activities. Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy gari wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of mangoes, avocados and flavours.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia  is 28 years-old and single with one nine year-old child.  For the past one year, she has been running her business. She earns a monthly income of about KES. 6,000 which she saves and also uses in the business.

She has been loaned KES. 10,000 from Kiva partner KADET Ltd. This is her first loan from KADET. She intends to use the loan to purchase stock like sugar flour, salt, rice, beans etc. to expand her business.

She plans to use the anticipated profit to start another business of trading clothes.  In the future, she hopes to buy a plot or piece of land to build.

loans.use: to purchase stock like  sugar flour, salt, rice, beans etc. to expand her business.

loans.name: Las Amazonas Group

texts.es:
Este comité es de la Ciudad de Caacupé, está integrado por 11 mujeres de la misma ciudad, todas ellas son vecinas y amigas. Tienen un fin en común que es el de conseguir más ingresos para llevarlos a la casa y de esa forma poder solventar los gastos diarios de la casa. Ellas trabajan en un ambiente de respeto, donde lo primordial es el trabajo en equipo y la solidaridad las unas con las otras.
La Señora Ramona, está casada y tiene hijos. Ella se dedica a la venta de bebidas desde hace unos años. Con esto ha podido ayudar a su marido en los gastos que implica mantener una casa. Comenta que tiene una gran demanda, especialmente los fines de semana gracias a que es muy conocida en el barrio, y en las zonas aledañas. Sueña con poder ampliar su negocio para poder tener más capacidad de almacenaje.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de cervezas, whiskys y vinos para abastecer su stock de bebidas. Está muy esperanzada en el crédito, ya que le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
The 11 women in this committee are from the city of Caacupé, they are all neighbors and friends in this city. They all have a goal in common, which is to earn more income to take home and so to be able to pay their daily household expenses. They work in a respectful manner, where the most important things are teamwork and solidarity, each looking out for the others. 
Ramona is married and has children. She has been working for some years selling drinks, and with this job she has been able to help her husband with the expenses that come with running their household. She comments that there is great demand for her goods, especially at the weekend. She is well known in the neighborhood and also in the surrounding areas. She dreams of being able to grow her business and have more storage capacity. 
She is requesting a loan to buy beer, whisky, and wine to increase her stock of drinks. She is very hopeful about the loan, as it will be a great help to her.

loans.use: Compra de cervezas, whiskys y vinos para abastecer su stock de bebidas

loans.name: Angélica María

texts.es:
Angélica es una joven emprendedora que debido a la falta de oportunidades para continuar con sus estudios universitarios aprendió al lado de una amiga de su madre el oficio de la peluquería canina, el cual convirtió en su propio negocio. Desde su casa Angélica ofrece sus servicios a sus vecinos, amigos y conocidos. 

Tener un local propio en el que pueda tener su peluquería canina es el sueño de Angélica quien para caminar hacia su meta, necesita por ahora de un préstamo para comprar medicamentos para mascotas, así como utensilios para su peluquería.
texts.en:
Angélica is a young entrepreneur who, due to a lack of opportunities to continue her university studies, learned pet grooming from a friend of her mother. She has turned this into her own business. Angélica works from home, offering her grooming services to neighbors, friends, and the people she knows.
She dreams of having her own store where she can groom dogs. As a step towards reaching this goal, right now she needs a loan to buy pet medication and also grooming tools.

loans.use: To buy pet medication and grooming tools

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi is a married woman with seven children.  She has two sets of twins.  Four of her children attend school while two are still young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a food vending business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is competition from other food vending businesses. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the loan of Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to establish a vegetable stall.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Margarita  tiene 35 años de edad, está casada, tiene tres hijos menores, vive en su propia casa, en la Ciudad de Caacupé.
La misma se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir y calzados en general. Por medio de este trabajo ella ha logrado generar un poco más de ingresos, con lo que ayuda a su marido. Ella está feliz ya que por medio de su trabajo puede ayudar a su familia y de esa forma ofrecerles un mejor estilo de vida. Su mayor sueño es que sus hijos sigan una carrera universitaria y así se conviertan en buenos profesionales. Quiere, algún día poder tener una tienda donde poder ofrecer sus productos.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas de temporadas, para satisfacer la demanda de su clientela, esto le permitirá obtener más ingresos a su unidad familiar.
texts.en:
Margarita is 35 years old, married, and has three young children. She lives in her own house in the city of Caacupé.
